data.question: What are the two porous metal organic frameworks (MOFs) mentioned for exceptional NO adsorption, storage, and delivery?
What triggers the release of stored NO gas in the MOFs?
data.answer: Contact with moisture triggers the release of stored NO gas.

data.question: How does the adsorption capacity of Co-MOF and Ni-MOF for NO compare to HKUST-1?
data.answer: Co-MOF and Ni-MOF adsorb twice as much NO as HKUST-1 at room temperature.

data.question: What is the role of coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (CUSs) in MOFs regarding NO adsorption?
data.answer: CUSs in MOFs strongly bind NO on adsorption, which is ideal for stable, long-shelf-life gas-storage applications.

data.question: What is the significance of the NO molecule's coordination to the metal atom in the structure of Co-MOF and Ni-MOF?
data.answer: The coordination indicates that each unsaturated metal atom in the structure can bind to one NO molecule, contributing to the high adsorption capacity.

data.question: What experimental method was used to locate the NO molecule chemisorbed on the cobalt atom of the Co-MOF framework?
data.answer: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to locate the NO molecule chemisorbed on the cobalt atom.

data.question: How does the release rate of NO from Co-MOF and Ni-MOF compare when in contact with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS)?
data.answer: The release rate of NO from both Co-MOF and Ni-MOF increases markedly in contact with PBS, with the half-life of NO delivery reduced to approximately 10 minutes.

data.question: What is the effect of NO-releasing MOFs on porcine arterial tissue?
data.answer: NO-releasing MOFs cause relaxation of porcine arterial tissue, demonstrating their biological activity.

data.question: Why is controlled delivery of pure NO important for medical applications?
data.answer: Controlled delivery of pure NO is important to reduce unwanted side reactions and limit inflammatory responses in human tissue.

data.question: What challenges are associated with the activation stage of MOF-74/CPO-27-Zn compared to other MOFs?
data.answer: The activation stage for MOF-74/CPO-27-Zn is not as easy due to several phase transitions and the framework undergoing considerable strain upon dehydration.

data.question: Is the entire reservoir of stored NO gas in Co-MOF and Ni-MOF recoverable after several months of storage?
Does exposure to moisture decrease the NO storage capacity of Co-MOF and Ni-MOF?
Is the toxicology of cobalt and nickel a limiting factor for the in vivo application of Co-MOF and Ni-MOF?
Can the NO-loaded MOFs release NO gas upon exposure to dry conditions?
Is the adsorption capacity of Co-MOF and Ni-MOF for NO gas significantly higher than that of zeolites?
Do Co-MOF and Ni-MOF release carcinogenic or pro-inflammatory side products along with NO?
Is the activation process for Co-MOF and Ni-MOF simpler than for HKUST-1?
